intro: Juncus brachyphyllus, commonly known as the short-leaf rush, is a perennial plant native to wetland and marshy environments in North America. It is characterized by its dense, cylindrical clusters of grass-like leaves that are typically less than 10 centimeters in length. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers in late summer, which are arranged in spike-like inflorescences. It thrives in saturated soils and is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and filter water. Juncus brachyphyllus plays an important role in wetland ecosystems by providing habitat for various invertebrates and birds.
